tags: rant about a comic nobody on hear reads over thank you for coming to my ted talk
summary: The thing with King Kid is like. that's an abused kid, right? He had a terrible home life ran away and found a magical place!...
body:
The thing with King Kid is like. that’s an abused kid, right? He had a terrible home life ran away and found a magical place! Where he and all the other abused and abandoned kids could have fun!! Be safe! And then people show up that he thinks are going to be his family and then one of them turns out to be an adult? And then ALL of them turn into adults? Of course he’s scared! Of course he’s pissed! Did you see those others kids that were absolutely terrified of Billy? That doesn’t make them or King Kid evil!

Anyway they’ll probably reveal something and it’ll turn out KK was evil to everyone all along but the more I think about it the more I think I would hate that tbh. They don’t have to add him to the permanent main characters, he can stay and rule over funland and the others visit from time to time when they need help or want to hang out, but don’t make him evil! That’s so cheap!

summary: The men spreading rumours that Marvel hired a “butt double” for Brie Larson just prove how INFURIATED they are when they cant...
body: The men spreading rumours that Marvel hired a “butt double” for Brie Larson just prove how INFURIATED they are when they cant sexually objectify a woman. They want to believe that Marvel would prioritize a woman’s ass as much as they do. And they’ll body shame the fuck out of a woman for not being curvy, and just shame her in general for not wearing a dumb and revealing outfit. One well-designed supersuit really threatened misogynists that bad

summary: Two more figures from Marvel’s Legends line promoting the MCU’s “Captain Marvel”. The first is labeled Genis Vell. In the comics...
body:
Two more figures from Marvel’s Legends line promoting the MCU’s “Captain Marvel”. The first is labeled Genis Vell. In the comics Genis is Mar Vell’s son.


The next figure is labeled Yon Rogg. In the comics (as described in Wikipedia) he’s a Kerr Commander and a foe of Captain Marvel (Carol Danvers) and was indirectly responsible for her transformation into Ms. Marvel.” We’ll see if that translates into a plot point in the movie. At IMDb, Jude Law is identified as playing Rogg in the movie.


(At this time, no actor in IMDb is listed as playing Genis Vell.)

summary: A Further Clarification of my Position Towards Brie Larson and a Response to ‘hug-annoy’
title: A Further Clarification of my Position Towards Brie Larson and a Response to ‘hug-annoy’
body:
Earlier this week, a made a post wherein a linked a youtube video I had found that did a good job with summarising my own position regarding the Rotten Tomatoes controversy involving the removal of the ‘don’t want to see’ option.

https://jolleiq.tumblr.com/post/183074679412/i-wanted-to-make-a-post-of-my-own-but-randomly

As a response, the user @hug-annoy pointed out the following (cropped for clarity reasons, you can find the original under the link above but I’ve left nothing out):

Along with their argument, the user provided me with a link to the following article: https://www.marieclaire.co.uk/entertainment/tv-and-film/brie-larson-641750#IGBy6mWlbqbT5ZGZ.99

I would like to take this response as an opportunity to show what I mean when I say that one should always read everything carefully and never leave out important pieces of information, as well as read the words themselves with care.

Let me start off by completing the statement above:

“About a year ago, I started paying attention to what my press days looked like and the critics reviewing movies, and noticed it appeared to be overwhelmingly white male. So, I spoke to Dr Stacy Smith at the USC Annenberg Inclusion Initiative, who put together a study to confirm that. Moving forward, I decided to make sure my press days were more inclusive. After speaking with you, the film critic Valerie Complex and a few other women of colour, it sounded like across the board they weren’t getting the same opportunities as others. When I talked to the facilities that weren’t providing it, they all had different excuses.”

I’ll comment about this in a minute, but for now, I would like everyone reading this to take a good 5 seconds and tell me why I found the last bit so important.

5…

4…

3…

2…

1…

Time’s up! For those of you with a keen eye, you’ll have noticed the word that gives away Brie’s act lies at the very end of the sentence: ‘excuses.’

Oh, but Mr. Bollywood! You’re just being silly! It’s just an ordinary word!

Well, yes, as a linguist, I agree, it is just an ordinary word. But it’s not the word itself that is problematic, but rather the specific use of that specific word in that specific sentence in that specific context.

Let’s play a little game called: Spot the difference!

S1: When I talked to the facilities that weren’t providing it, they all had different excuses.

S2: When I talked to the facilities that weren’t providing it, they all had different reasons.

A subtle difference to spot, but one that changes the meaning entirely. The second is simply an observation and a valid position, but the first has an implicit negative connotation. It’s difficult to spot and I can’t really blame anyone for not spotting it, but with the implicit negative connotation that Brie assigned to the sentence, she revealed her inner bias. She wasn’t interested in hearing the reasons as to why the majority of film critics were white males, she was specifically looking for excuses, meaning that she had already decided that no matter the answer, every answer was just an excuse and not a valid reason. Unfortunately for her, some people do spot this, and those people can tell when someone is looking to fight for justice or fight for an agenda, and she made it clear that she is doing the latter. If you go out looking for excuses, you’ll find excuses, and if you go out looking for reasons, you’ll find reasons, the key difference being the excuses will always have a negative connotation, whereas reasons could be both good and bad.

As for the other part, I tracked it down to this article: https://boundingintocomics.com/2019/02/11/brie-larson-doubles-down-wants-fewer-white-men-on-captain-marvel-press-tour/

Again, let’s play a game of spot the difference! 

S1: “For the third time, I don’t hate black dudes. These are just facts. These are not my feelings. Am I saying I hate black dudes? No, I am not. What I am saying is you make a movie that is a love letter to white men, there is an insanely low chance a white man will have a chance to see your movie, and review your movie.”

S2:  “For the third time, I don’t hate white dudes. These are just facts. These are not my feelings. Am I saying I hate white dudes? No, I am not. What I am saying is you make a movie that is a love letter to women of color, there is an insanely low chance a woman of color will have a chance to see your movie, and review your movie.”

S1 “I don’t need a 40-year-old black woman to tell me what didn’t work about Captain America. It wasn’t made for her! I want to know what it meant to white men, biracial boys, to teen boys.”

S2:  “I don’t need a 40-year-old white dude to tell me what didn’t work about A Wrinkle in Time. It wasn’t made for him! I want to know what it meant to women of color, biracial women, to teen women of color, to teens that are biracial.“

It’s amazing how replacing a few words can turn a whole paragraph on its head, isn’t it?

All poor jokes aside, I agree that the numbers of film critics are disproportionate, but rather than look for excuses, look for reasons and then evaluate those reasons.

Had Brie replaced ‘white male’ with any other word, the social media would have bombarded her, but they didn’t, because as long as it is a white male that is in the bad spotlight, it’s okay, and this is the problem I am trying to point out and why I called her racist and sexist, as well as why so many are outraged. The narrative that is being pushed to stop racism and sexism is itself sexist and racist, and I stand against this.

Has she phrased it as: “I wish to make my press tour more inclusive to give every reporter, regardless of gender or colour, an equal voice in the matter, and find out the reasons why there is such a discrepancy between the number of reporters who are white men and those who are not, to find out whether there exists some barrier preventing others from attaining such positions, or if there are valid reasons for it,” she would have gotten my and many other’s full support, because this is what being a progressive and being all-inclusive is. But when you single out a particular group of people and give advantage to all others, and see any reason as just an excuse, that’s when you’re being biassed and prejudiced.

Also, why does it matter who the film is made for or who reviews it? The movie should not be judged by whether or not it met the desires of a specific audience, but it should be judged by itself and whether it was good or not. Yes, you can make it for a specific audience and value their opinions more highly than others’, that’s fine, but if I happen to watch the movie and not like certain aspects of it, telling me that my voice doesn’t matter because I’m not a specific skin colour or sex is both racist and sexist by definition. Were I to pull the same thing as I jokingly did above, I’d receive a wave of hate for being sexist and racist and prejudiced, but when someone else does it who isn’t white or male, it’s ok.

“Your opinion of A Wrinkle in Time doesn’t matter because you’re a white male.”

“Your opinion about Iron Man doesn’t matter because you’re a black woman.”

I see no difference in the two. Both are equally sexist and racist, and that’s what Brie and the media backing her refuse to understand. Even if the movie wasn’t made specifically for me, I can still like or dislike it and I have the full right to comment on it, as do other people about other movies. That’s how equality works.

I hope I’ve made my position clear this time.

- B. S.

Again, let’s play a game of spot the difference! 

S1: “For the third time, I don’t hate black dudes. These are just facts. These are not my feelings. Am I saying I hate black dudes? No, I am not. What I am saying is you make a movie that is a love letter to white men, there is an insanely low chance a white man will have a chance to see your movie, and review your movie.”

S2:  “For the third time, I don’t hate white dudes. These are just facts. These are not my feelings. Am I saying I hate white dudes? No, I am not. What I am saying is you make a movie that is a love letter to women of color, there is an insanely low chance a woman of color will have a chance to see your movie, and review your movie.”

S1 “I don’t need a 40-year-old black woman to tell me what didn’t work about Captain America. It wasn’t made for her! I want to know what it meant to white men, biracial boys, to teen boys.”

S2:  “I don’t need a 40-year-old white dude to tell me what didn’t work about A Wrinkle in Time. It wasn’t made for him! I want to know what it meant to women of color, biracial women, to teen women of color, to teens that are biracial.“

It’s amazing how replacing a few words can turn a whole paragraph on its head, isn’t it?

All poor jokes aside, I agree that the numbers of film critics are disproportionate, but rather than look for excuses, look for reasons and then evaluate those reasons.

Had Brie replaced ‘white male’ with any other word, the social media would have bombarded her, but they didn’t, because as long as it is a white male that is in the bad spotlight, it’s okay, and this is the problem I am trying to point out and why I called her racist and sexist, as well as why so many are outraged. The narrative that is being pushed to stop racism and sexism is itself sexist and racist, and I stand against this.

Has she phrased it as: “I wish to make my press tour more inclusive to give every reporter, regardless of gender or colour, an equal voice in the matter, and find out the reasons why there is such a discrepancy between the number of reporters who are white men and those who are not, to find out whether there exists some barrier preventing others from attaining such positions, or if there are valid reasons for it,” she would have gotten my and many other’s full support, because this is what being a progressive and being all-inclusive is. But when you single out a particular group of people and give advantage to all others, and see any reason as just an excuse, that’s when you’re being biassed and prejudiced.

Also, why does it matter who the film is made for or who reviews it? The movie should not be judged by whether or not it met the desires of a specific audience, but it should be judged by itself and whether it was good or not. Yes, you can make it for a specific audience and value their opinions more highly than others’, that’s fine, but if I happen to watch the movie and not like certain aspects of it, telling me that my voice doesn’t matter because I’m not a specific skin colour or sex is both racist and sexist by definition. Were I to pull the same thing as I jokingly did above, I’d receive a wave of hate for being sexist and racist and prejudiced, but when someone else does it who isn’t white or male, it’s ok.

“Your opinion of A Wrinkle in Time doesn’t matter because you’re a white male.”

“Your opinion about Iron Man doesn’t matter because you’re a black woman.”

I see no difference in the two. Both are equally sexist and racist, and that’s what Brie and the media backing her refuse to understand. Even if the movie wasn’t made specifically for me, I can still like or dislike it and I have the full right to comment on it, as do other people about other movies. That’s how equality works.

I hope I’ve made my position clear this time.

- B. S.
trail.content:
Earlier this week, a made a post wherein a linked a youtube video I had found that did a good job with summarising my own position regarding the Rotten Tomatoes controversy involving the removal of the ‘don’t want to see’ option.

https://jolleiq.tumblr.com/post/183074679412/i-wanted-to-make-a-post-of-my-own-but-randomly

As a response, the user @hug-annoy pointed out the following (cropped for clarity reasons, you can find the original under the link above but I’ve left nothing out):

Along with their argument, the user provided me with a link to the following article: https://www.marieclaire.co.uk/entertainment/tv-and-film/brie-larson-641750#IGBy6mWlbqbT5ZGZ.99

I would like to take this response as an opportunity to show what I mean when I say that one should always read everything carefully and never leave out important pieces of information, as well as read the words themselves with care.

Let me start off by completing the statement above:

“About a year ago, I started paying attention to what my press days looked like and the critics reviewing movies, and noticed it appeared to be overwhelmingly white male. So, I spoke to Dr Stacy Smith at the USC Annenberg Inclusion Initiative, who put together a study to confirm that. Moving forward, I decided to make sure my press days were more inclusive. After speaking with you, the film critic Valerie Complex and a few other women of colour, it sounded like across the board they weren’t getting the same opportunities as others. When I talked to the facilities that weren’t providing it, they all had different excuses.”

I’ll comment about this in a minute, but for now, I would like everyone reading this to take a good 5 seconds and tell me why I found the last bit so important.

5…

4…

3…

2…

1…

Time’s up! For those of you with a keen eye, you’ll have noticed the word that gives away Brie’s act lies at the very end of the sentence: ‘excuses.’

Oh, but Mr. Bollywood! You’re just being silly! It’s just an ordinary word!

Well, yes, as a linguist, I agree, it is just an ordinary word. But it’s not the word itself that is problematic, but rather the specific use of that specific word in that specific sentence in that specific context.

Let’s play a little game called: Spot the difference!

S1: When I talked to the facilities that weren’t providing it, they all had different excuses.

S2: When I talked to the facilities that weren’t providing it, they all had different reasons.

A subtle difference to spot, but one that changes the meaning entirely. The second is simply an observation and a valid position, but the first has an implicit negative connotation. It’s difficult to spot and I can’t really blame anyone for not spotting it, but with the implicit negative connotation that Brie assigned to the sentence, she revealed her inner bias. She wasn’t interested in hearing the reasons as to why the majority of film critics were white males, she was specifically looking for excuses, meaning that she had already decided that no matter the answer, every answer was just an excuse and not a valid reason. Unfortunately for her, some people do spot this, and those people can tell when someone is looking to fight for justice or fight for an agenda, and she made it clear that she is doing the latter. If you go out looking for excuses, you’ll find excuses, and if you go out looking for reasons, you’ll find reasons, the key difference being the excuses will always have a negative connotation, whereas reasons could be both good and bad.

As for the other part, I tracked it down to this article: https://boundingintocomics.com/2019/02/11/brie-larson-doubles-down-wants-fewer-white-men-on-captain-marvel-press-tour/

Again, let’s play a game of spot the difference! 

S1: “For the third time, I don’t hate black dudes. These are just facts. These are not my feelings. Am I saying I hate black dudes? No, I am not. What I am saying is you make a movie that is a love letter to white men, there is an insanely low chance a white man will have a chance to see your movie, and review your movie.”

S2:  “For the third time, I don’t hate white dudes. These are just facts. These are not my feelings. Am I saying I hate white dudes? No, I am not. What I am saying is you make a movie that is a love letter to women of color, there is an insanely low chance a woman of color will have a chance to see your movie, and review your movie.”

S1 “I don’t need a 40-year-old black woman to tell me what didn’t work about Captain America. It wasn’t made for her! I want to know what it meant to white men, biracial boys, to teen boys.”

S2:  “I don’t need a 40-year-old white dude to tell me what didn’t work about A Wrinkle in Time. It wasn’t made for him! I want to know what it meant to women of color, biracial women, to teen women of color, to teens that are biracial.“

It’s amazing how replacing a few words can turn a whole paragraph on its head, isn’t it?

All poor jokes aside, I agree that the numbers of film critics are disproportionate, but rather than look for excuses, look for reasons and then evaluate those reasons.

Had Brie replaced ‘white male’ with any other word, the social media would have bombarded her, but they didn’t, because as long as it is a white male that is in the bad spotlight, it’s okay, and this is the problem I am trying to point out and why I called her racist and sexist, as well as why so many are outraged. The narrative that is being pushed to stop racism and sexism is itself sexist and racist, and I stand against this.

Has she phrased it as: “I wish to make my press tour more inclusive to give every reporter, regardless of gender or colour, an equal voice in the matter, and find out the reasons why there is such a discrepancy between the number of reporters who are white men and those who are not, to find out whether there exists some barrier preventing others from attaining such positions, or if there are valid reasons for it,” she would have gotten my and many other’s full support, because this is what being a progressive and being all-inclusive is. But when you single out a particular group of people and give advantage to all others, and see any reason as just an excuse, that’s when you’re being biassed and prejudiced.

Also, why does it matter who the film is made for or who reviews it? The movie should not be judged by whether or not it met the desires of a specific audience, but it should be judged by itself and whether it was good or not. Yes, you can make it for a specific audience and value their opinions more highly than others’, that’s fine, but if I happen to watch the movie and not like certain aspects of it, telling me that my voice doesn’t matter because I’m not a specific skin colour or sex is both racist and sexist by definition. Were I to pull the same thing as I jokingly did above, I’d receive a wave of hate for being sexist and racist and prejudiced, but when someone else does it who isn’t white or male, it’s ok.

“Your opinion of A Wrinkle in Time doesn’t matter because you’re a white male.”

“Your opinion about Iron Man doesn’t matter because you’re a black woman.”

I see no difference in the two. Both are equally sexist and racist, and that’s what Brie and the media backing her refuse to understand. Even if the movie wasn’t made specifically for me, I can still like or dislike it and I have the full right to comment on it, as do other people about other movies. That’s how equality works.

I hope I’ve made my position clear this time.

- B. S.

tags: i'm totally calling out that motherfucker from my last post
summary: “I won’t see Captain Marvel because superhero movies shouldn’t be political, they’re entertainment!” muh muh muh shut the fuck...
body:
“I won’t see Captain Marvel because superhero movies shouldn’t be political, they’re entertainment!” muh muh muh shut the fuck up Tim we all know you see legitimate female leads as a ‘feminist threat’ because in your head Straight White Man is the default and any alteration to this formula suddenly makes it a political message. 

Evidence #1: Captain America: the Winter Solider is regarded as one of the MCU’s G.O.A.T.s but people were sure entertained by a movie rebelliously commenting on military industrialism, government spying on the population, and extrajudicial violence. Heavy stuff compared to implying girls don’t need to wear skintight catsuits and bat their eyelashes at men in order to kick some ass.

summary: Captain Marvel is not even out yet and I’m already in love with her and Brie
body:
Captain Marvel is not even out yet and I’m already in love with her and Brie

She has the same big dick energy as RDJ/Tony and is also so breathtakingly beautiful…I was afraid that after Endgame when Tony/RDJ will leave I will never love someone in MCU as much as him but she gave me hope that Endgame will be not the end

Look isn’t she amazing

summary: Movie review site, Rotten Tomatoes is in the process of implementing changes to their website. Moving forward, users will not be...
body:
Movie review site, Rotten Tomatoes is in the process of implementing changes to their website. Moving forward, users will not be able to comment on a film prior to the film’s release. This new change should prevent users from posting negative reviews about a movie prior to it being released to give it a false score.

This move came shortly after Internet Trolls started to comment on Captain Marvel’s Rotten Tomatoes page and giving it negative feedback. This “Review-Bombing” was to purposefully lower the film’s Audience Rating. As a result, the film is currently the lowest-rated MCU film on the website.

Shazam! Star Zachary Levi decided to confront the trolls head in an Instagram video where he tells people that “This is not helping anyone or anything.”

Here’s @ZacharyLevi asking fans to stop piting #CaptainMarvel and #Shazam against each other, because IT ISN’T HELPING ANYONE. He’s also calling out the fake reviews and fabricated/defamatory posts about @brielarson. —It’s time for those people to really listen. pic.twitter.com/SzL0iowj5T

— 𝓪𝓁𝒾𝒶𝓈 (@itsjustanx) February 24, 2019


Currently, if you head to the Rotten Tomatoes website, you will now see that the ‘Want to See’ percentage score has been changed to just a number. Rotten Tomatoes states that additional changes to the site’s reviewing and filtering systems will possibly come later this year.

 

Sylvester Stallone is bringing John Rambo back out of retirement. The Hollywood Reporter reported? Did that sound weird? That Rambo: Last Blood is set to hit theaters on September 20th 2019. This will be Sly’s final performance as John Rambo in this fifth installment of this franchise.

In this film, Rambo will be searching for a friend’s daughter who has been kidnapped and brought across the U.S. – Mexico border. Rambo will be fighting a different war as he takes on one of Mexico’s most violent cartels.

Serigo Peris-Mencheta will be playing Hugo Martinez, the leader of the cartel and the main protagonist of the film. He will be joined by Yvette Monreal as the daughter of Rambo’s friend and Paz Vega as Carmen Delgado, a reporter who teams up with Rambo to search for her kidnapped half-sister.

Yvette Monreal
Serigo Peris-Mencheta
Paz Vega

You can keep up with teases of the film by following Sylvester Stallone’s Instagram page. He has been posting little nuggets of information like Rambo’s new look. With the film being released this fall, we should expect to see a trailer in the coming months.

 

View this post on Instagram

… Comes a Horseman Wild and Free. @rambomovie #rambo5

A post shared by Sly Stallone (@officialslystallone) on Oct 2, 2018 at 11:36am PDT

And finally, all you Star Wars fans can rejoice because we are going to be getting our first official look at Star Wars: Fallen Jedi Order real soon. More specifically, On April 13th.


In a blog post on Starwars.com, it was announced that fans will get their first look at the new game during this year’s Star Wars Celebration in Chicago. “In a special panel on Saturday, April 13, EA and Respawn will pull back the curtain on Star Wars Jedi: Fallen Order, in which gamers will meet a Padawan who survived Order 66 and explore the galaxy in the time after the fall of the Jedi Order. The discussion will feature never-before-released details ahead of the game’s fall 2019 release.”

We hope this means a trailer and some gameplay footage will be shown. You can bet we will be covering any information about Star Wars: Fallen Jedi Order when it drops. Star Wars Celebration Chicago will take place April 11-15 at McCormick Place. Visit StarWarsCelebration.com for tickets and more info!

Rotten Tomatoes Makes Changes To Combat Trolls - This Week in Geek #CaptainMarvel #Shazam #RamboLastBlood #StarWarsFallenJediOrder #StarWarsCelebration Movie review site, Rotten Tomatoes is in the process of implementing changes to their website. Moving forward, users will not be able to comment on a film prior to the film’s release.

We hope this means a trailer and some gameplay footage will be shown. You can bet we will be covering any information about Star Wars: Fallen Jedi Order when it drops. Rotten Tomatoes Makes Changes To Combat Trolls - This Week in Geek #CaptainMarvel #Shazam #RamboLastBlood #StarWarsFallenJediOrder #StarWarsCelebration Movie review site, Rotten Tomatoes is in the process of implementing changes to their website. Moving forward, users will not be able to comment on a film prior to the film’s release.
trail.content:
Movie review site, Rotten Tomatoes is in the process of implementing changes to their website. Moving forward, users will not be able to comment on a film prior to the film’s release. This new change should prevent users from posting negative reviews about a movie prior to it being released to give it a false score.

This move came shortly after Internet Trolls started to comment on Captain Marvel’s Rotten Tomatoes page and giving it negative feedback. This “Review-Bombing” was to purposefully lower the film’s Audience Rating. As a result, the film is currently the lowest-rated MCU film on the website.

Shazam! Star Zachary Levi decided to confront the trolls head in an Instagram video where he tells people that “This is not helping anyone or anything.”

Here’s @ZacharyLevi asking fans to stop piting #CaptainMarvel and #Shazam against each other, because IT ISN’T HELPING ANYONE. He’s also calling out the fake reviews and fabricated/defamatory posts about @brielarson. —It’s time for those people to really listen. pic.twitter.com/SzL0iowj5T

— 𝓪𝓁𝒾𝒶𝓈 (@itsjustanx) February 24, 2019


Currently, if you head to the Rotten Tomatoes website, you will now see that the ‘Want to See’ percentage score has been changed to just a number. Rotten Tomatoes states that additional changes to the site’s reviewing and filtering systems will possibly come later this year.

 

Sylvester Stallone is bringing John Rambo back out of retirement. The Hollywood Reporter reported? Did that sound weird? That Rambo: Last Blood is set to hit theaters on September 20th 2019. This will be Sly’s final performance as John Rambo in this fifth installment of this franchise.

External image

In this film, Rambo will be searching for a friend’s daughter who has been kidnapped and brought across the U.S. – Mexico border. Rambo will be fighting a different war as he takes on one of Mexico’s most violent cartels.

Serigo Peris-Mencheta will be playing Hugo Martinez, the leader of the cartel and the main protagonist of the film. He will be joined by Yvette Monreal as the daughter of Rambo’s friend and Paz Vega as Carmen Delgado, a reporter who teams up with Rambo to search for her kidnapped half-sister.

External image
Yvette Monreal
External image
Serigo Peris-Mencheta
External image
Paz Vega

You can keep up with teases of the film by following Sylvester Stallone’s Instagram page. He has been posting little nuggets of information like Rambo’s new look. With the film being released this fall, we should expect to see a trailer in the coming months.

 

View this post on Instagram

… Comes a Horseman Wild and Free. @rambomovie #rambo5

A post shared by Sly Stallone (@officialslystallone) on Oct 2, 2018 at 11:36am PDT

And finally, all you Star Wars fans can rejoice because we are going to be getting our first official look at Star Wars: Fallen Jedi Order real soon. More specifically, On April 13th.

External image

In a blog post on Starwars.com, it was announced that fans will get their first look at the new game during this year’s Star Wars Celebration in Chicago. “In a special panel on Saturday, April 13, EA and Respawn will pull back the curtain on Star Wars Jedi: Fallen Order, in which gamers will meet a Padawan who survived Order 66 and explore the galaxy in the time after the fall of the Jedi Order. The discussion will feature never-before-released details ahead of the game’s fall 2019 release.”

We hope this means a trailer and some gameplay footage will be shown. You can bet we will be covering any information about Star Wars: Fallen Jedi Order when it drops. Star Wars Celebration Chicago will take place April 11-15 at McCormick Place. Visit StarWarsCelebration.com for tickets and more info!

Moving forward, users will not be able to comment on a film prior to the film’s release.
